natural problem:
Let $\mathbf{v}_1,$ $\mathbf{v}_2,$ $\dots,$ $\mathbf{v}_k$ be unit vectors such that
\[\mathbf{v}_1 + \mathbf{v}_2 + \dots + \mathbf{v}_k = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}.\]Find the smallest possible value of $k.$

Note: A unit vector is a vector of magnitude 1.
natural solution: We can express $\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}$ as the sum of 8 unit vectors, as shown below, so the smallest possible value of $k$ is $\boxed{8}.$ [asy] usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); int i;
} draw(A--B,red,Arrow(6)); draw(B--C,red,Arrow(6)); draw((-1,0)--(7,0)); draw((0,-6)--(0,1)); dot("$\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}$", (6,-5), SE); [/asy]

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real^2"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. norm (v n) = 1"
and h1 : "(\<Sum> i \<in> {1..k}. v i) = vector [6, -5]"
shows  "k \<ge> 8"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\mathbf{v}_1,$ $\mathbf{v}_2,$ $\dots,$ $\mathbf{v}_k$ be unit vectors such that
\[\mathbf{v}_1 + \mathbf{v}_2 + \dots + \mathbf{v}_k = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}.\]Find the smallest possible value of $k.$

Note: A unit vector is a vector of magnitude 1. The final Answer is 8
 ### Proof
 By the Triangle Inequality, \[\|\mathbf{v}_1 + \mathbf{v}_2 + \dots + \mathbf{v}_k\| \le  \|\mathbf{v}_1\| + \|\mathbf{v}_2\| + \dots + \|\mathbf{v}_k\| = k.\]Then \[k \ge \left\|\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix} \right\| = \sqrt{61} > \sqrt{49} = 7,\]so $k \ge 8.$
 We can express $\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}$ as the sum of 8 unit vectors, as shown below, so the smallest possible value of $k$ is $\boxed{8}.$ [asy] usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); int i;
 pair A, B, C; A = 6*(6,-5)/abs((6,-5)); C = (6,-5); B = intersectionpoint(arc(A,1,-45,0),arc(C,1,90,180)); for (i = 0; i <= 5; ++i) {   draw(i*(6,-5)/abs((6,-5))--(i + 1)*(6,-5)/abs((6,-5)),red,Arrow(6));
 } draw(A--B,red,Arrow(6)); draw(B--C,red,Arrow(6)); draw((-1,0)--(7,0)); draw((0,-6)--(0,1)); dot("$\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}$", (6,-5), SE); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes v :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real^2"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. norm (v n) = 1"
and h1 : "(\<Sum> i \<in> {1..k}. v i) = vector [6, -5]"
shows  "k \<ge> 8"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given a sequence of two-dimensional vectors $v_n$ such that the norm (length) of each vector is 1, find the smallest integer $k$ such that the sum of the first $k$ vectors is the vector [6, -5]. The final answer is that $k$ should be greater than or equal to 8.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real^2" 
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. i \<in> {1..k} \<longrightarrow> norm(v i) = 1"
and h1 : "setsum v {1..k} = vector [6, -5]"
shows  "k \<ge> 8"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\mathbf{v}_1,$ $\mathbf{v}_2,$ $\dots,$ $\mathbf{v}_k$ be unit vectors such that
\[\mathbf{v}_1 + \mathbf{v}_2 + \dots + \mathbf{v}_k = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}.\]Find the smallest possible value of $k.$

Note: A unit vector is a vector of magnitude 1. The final Answer is 8
 ### Proof
 By the Triangle Inequality, \[\|\mathbf{v}_1 + \mathbf{v}_2 + \dots + \mathbf{v}_k\| \le  \|\mathbf{v}_1\| + \|\mathbf{v}_2\| + \dots + \|\mathbf{v}_k\| = k.\]Then \[k \ge \left\|\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix} \right\| = \sqrt{61} > \sqrt{49} = 7,\]so $k \ge 8.$
 We can express $\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}$ as the sum of 8 unit vectors, as shown below, so the smallest possible value of $k$ is $\boxed{8}.$ [asy] usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); int i;
 pair A, B, C; A = 6*(6,-5)/abs((6,-5)); C = (6,-5); B = intersectionpoint(arc(A,1,-45,0),arc(C,1,90,180)); for (i = 0; i <= 5; ++i) {   draw(i*(6,-5)/abs((6,-5))--(i + 1)*(6,-5)/abs((6,-5)),red,Arrow(6));
 } draw(A--B,red,Arrow(6)); draw(B--C,red,Arrow(6)); draw((-1,0)--(7,0)); draw((0,-6)--(0,1)); dot("$\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}$", (6,-5), SE); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes v :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real^2" 
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i. i \<in> {1..k} \<longrightarrow> norm(v i) = 1"
and h1 : "setsum v {1..k} = vector [6, -5]"
shows  "k \<ge> 8"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real^2"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. i \<le> k \<longrightarrow> norm (v i) = 1"
and h1 : "sum v {..k} = vector [6, -5]"
and h2 : "k = (LEAST k. \<exists> v. (\<forall> i. i \<le> k \<longrightarrow> norm (v i) = 1) \<and> sum v {..k} = vector [6, -5])"
shows  "k = 8"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $\mathbf{v}_1,$ $\mathbf{v}_2,$ $\dots,$ $\mathbf{v}_k$ be unit vectors such that
\[\mathbf{v}_1 + \mathbf{v}_2 + \dots + \mathbf{v}_k = \begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}.\]Find the smallest possible value of $k.$

Note: A unit vector is a vector of magnitude 1. The final Answer is 8
 ### Proof
 By the Triangle Inequality, \[\|\mathbf{v}_1 + \mathbf{v}_2 + \dots + \mathbf{v}_k\| \le  \|\mathbf{v}_1\| + \|\mathbf{v}_2\| + \dots + \|\mathbf{v}_k\| = k.\]Then \[k \ge \left\|\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix} \right\| = \sqrt{61} > \sqrt{49} = 7,\]so $k \ge 8.$
 We can express $\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}$ as the sum of 8 unit vectors, as shown below, so the smallest possible value of $k$ is $\boxed{8}.$ [asy] usepackage("amsmath"); unitsize(1 cm); int i;
 pair A, B, C; A = 6*(6,-5)/abs((6,-5)); C = (6,-5); B = intersectionpoint(arc(A,1,-45,0),arc(C,1,90,180)); for (i = 0; i <= 5; ++i) {   draw(i*(6,-5)/abs((6,-5))--(i + 1)*(6,-5)/abs((6,-5)),red,Arrow(6));
 } draw(A--B,red,Arrow(6)); draw(B--C,red,Arrow(6)); draw((-1,0)--(7,0)); draw((0,-6)--(0,1)); dot("$\begin{pmatrix} 6 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}$", (6,-5), SE); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes v :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real^2"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i. i \<le> k \<longrightarrow> norm (v i) = 1"
and h1 : "sum v {..k} = vector [6, -5]"
and h2 : "k = (LEAST k. \<exists> v. (\<forall> i. i \<le> k \<longrightarrow> norm (v i) = 1) \<and> sum v {..k} = vector [6, -5])"
shows  "k = 8"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
